reviewText:
I have been playing UnReal World since 2004. If the game clocked hours before it came to Steam I would be in the thousands. So let's talk about URW.

URW is a roguelike survival game set in Iron Age Finland. It has been made (mostly) by one person and has been in development since 1992. That's 24 years. Talk about dedication.

You survive through the four seasons by hunting, gathering, fishing, trading, trapping and farming. You can make a huge variety of items ranging from wooden pots to your very own house and sauna. You will learn the importance of shelter, fire and the advantages of a ranged weapon. Will you be a fisherman hermit? A travelling merchant? Or maybe a proud warrior? You can play the game however you want.

There's a steep learning curve to the game since there is simply so much to do. The number of hotkeys on the keyboard rivals Microsoft Flight Simulator. The game does have a good manual and plenty of flavor text for history geeks. And let's not forget the lovely LARP pictures for all the characters.

Venture into the Far North. And don't forget to tan your hides.

reviewText:
What to say about this amazing game?

Just play it!

Okay, no, that's not fair... you probably want more info than that, right?

TL;DR
God-tier survival/crafting roguelike. Considerable learning curve. Awesome community & devs. Unlike anything else you're likely to find. Try it for free: http://unrealworld.fi/

General Info
It's certainly not for everyone... but it's also one of the most unique and fun games I've ever had the pleasure of playing (that's coming from someone who's been playing video games for over 20 years, and with over 1000 games on Steam alone).

Roguelikes, as a genre, seem to have had a resurgence in popularity in recent years; ever since Minecraft rocked the gaming world, the whole survival-crafting-building genre has only increased in popularity.

UnReal World mixes all of this and gives you a peerless roguelike survival crafting experience. There are no zombies to find here, only bears and Njerpez (not to mention the hunger and cold), but they're more than trouble enough. You'll wish you had something as easy as zombies to deal with! (except, no, hopefully not... no more zombies... too many zombies everywhere)

Despite its name, UnReal World also provides one of the most realistic survival experiences I've seen in a game to date (probably the most realistic, really).

Do you want to hang out in the highly-populated Driik lands for access to their large villages and have an easy life of crafting and trading? Or perhaps you'd prefer living out in the middle of nowhere to see if you can survive completely on your own, without help from anyone? Maybe you want to see a lot of combat and one day hope to eradicate all the Njerpez?

Any of this is possible, and so much more. It's up to you.

Gameplay
UnReal World won't hold your hand; iron-age pseudo-Finland is a brutal place in which to try and survive, no doubt.

A lot of modern gamers might be turned off by the initial time investment required to learn how to play the game (not to mention the oldschool graphics; no fancy 3D & particle effects here), but for those that bother, they'll be rewarded with incredibly deep survival gameplay and an experience like no other.

The keyboard-based nature of the game might seem unwieldly at first (and yes, there are a lot of keys to memorize) but it offers very smooth gameplay once you get used to it. You can use the mouse for most/a lot of things, but I'd suggest gtting used to the hotkeys; they can drastically improve your experience.

UnReal World is a sandbox. There are no set goals beyond survive". How you go about doing that is up to you.

reviewText:
I've played various versions of UnReal World over the past 12+ years, including dozens of hours on this latest version which is being released on Steam. It's got a lot of attributes of a rogue-like: turn-based movement, permanent death, lots of stuff to discover, lots of stuff to craft. Somewhere in its development, more than 10 years ago, it strayed from the path of being a fantasy game to being a simulation of iron-age Finland.

The combat system is straight-forward, but unforgiving. The character has skills for various weapons; combat results are based on attacker and defender results; damage is allocated to hit locations after accounting for armor. Positioning matters: getting behind an opponent allows unblocked attacks. Injuries matter: serious blows to the legs can lame or cripple a creature, a hard blow to the head or even torso can stun. Combat can be drawn out or over quickly, depending on the hidden rng and positioning, so new players are advised to tread carefully at first. Or, you can accept that it's a rogue-like, and just get killed and restart.

If your character can survive or avoid combats, time will pass. You'll have to keep your character fed or starvation penalties will mount. You'll have to think about water, and warmth, and shelter. And eventually, maybe before your character is fully prepared, winter will arrive. In the UnReal World, winter changes the game. For about five game-months you need to stay warm and stay fed. Every day will be short. Every night will be long. The leading cause of death in winter might be boredom; the cabin fever and the routine of safe survival becomes too much and the player takes a character out to adventure in the great white north, into the teeth of a blizzard. Some of them make it back to their cabins. Having said that, with good fur clothes and ski equipment, a character can do a lot of hunting and trapping through the winter, or timberwork, or any number of other tasks.

I think my characters have died every way possible in this game. I'll let you discover the various ways, and head off myself for further adventures. Enjoy!

Even if you're totally enamoured with this game by the looks of the descriptions and reviews, I still urge people to play the free version before grabbing the Steam one. Once you've given it a shot, you can make a much better decision on if you want to drop money on it. I told myself that if I played the free version for longer than eight hours, I'd buy the Steam version even if I never boot it up again. I clocked about ten hours, bought it on Steam, then continued to play it for however long it says I have at the top of this review.

reviewText:
(Please ignore the small amount of play-time I have. I've had this game for around a decade, and the developer has kindly supplied me with a key for the Steam version.)

See the bottom of the review for TL;DR.

I rarely write positive reviews, but to me, the devotion that Sami shows to his supporters and fans is nothing short of remarkable. He went through the trouble of walking me through the steps of getting my key re-sent and updated despite me having very little of the original information I had when originally purchasing the game, and also has made a point of giving Steam keys to those who own lifetime registration keys.

Though, this is a review about URW, not about the developer.

URW takes a somewhat different approach to things than a lot of roguelikes, especially the ones usually seen on Steam. Rather than abstracting concepts like HP, satiation, exhaustion, deities, combat, and so on, URW tries as well as it is able to approach things more realistically. Fans of Dwarf Fortress Adventurer Mode shouldn't be too out of their element here.

Rather than being about killing dragons and getting amulets, URW is more generally about surviving in the wilderness. Trying to, anyway. Combat poses a very real threat. One missed blow could get you a concussion, or swept off of your feet and getting a spear through your chest, or teeth at your throat. This is made all the more painful, because your characters and the worlds they live in are indeed very permanent. You might build a house and make a type of farm, trading regularly with a nearby village. Make a smokehouse to cure your meats, make a sauna, get drunk, do what people from Finland do.

But the combat itself isn't the only problem. You also have to worry about things like your wounds getting infected, illnesses, starvation, dehydration, hypothermia, sleep deprivation. Of course, when you're injured, it becomes even harder to care for yourself... but that might be skipping ahead a little too far. Depending on whatever choice of background and scenario you pick, your first priority might be making a temporary shelter out of sticks and leaves, fending off a wolf, or escaping from captivity.

After you make yourself marginally more comfortable, you need to start working on feeding yourself, and making (or trading for, or looting, or stealing) tools as a means to accomplish this. Whether that means hunting for food, fishing, foraging, robbing other people, stealing from them, or just plain killing them and eating them. (The gods won't mind. Really.) But while eating raw food might be okay sometimes, you should probably consider cooking it, making a dish of it, or maybe a bit later on, working on a means of preparing it for long-term storage, like digging a cold-storage cellar, or curing it with salt, or in a smokehouse.

Once you have a somewhat reliable means of feeding yourself and living comfortably in the trees, and have a nice axe, hopefully without too many people's blood on it, you could think about building a house for yourself! Or you could live like a nomad. Your choice, really. Either way, once you're on your feet, you can get niceties by trading things like cured furs and pelts to village traders and other wanderers possibly like yourself.

Although there are arbitrary goals that can reward you with things, ultimately they are optional and there is no endgame or final goal of URW besides what you dictate.

URW is definitely not for everyone, and I do recommend trying the free version first. Don't let my review make the game sound more hypeworthy than it is. See for yourself if you like it or not. Even if you think you like roguelikes, this one might not sit well with you.

tl;dr Mostly-realistic wilderness survival roguelike that eventually turns into a violent Harvest Moon with permadeath.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for years, and I'm so glad it's finally on Steam.

(Back when I started, my main enemy was falling out of trees, and if you slept out in the open, you'd wake up to a lynx ripping your face off. I'm fairly sure that latter one can still happen. Don't mess with lynxes. Their silent meows are a premonition of terror and violence.)

I'm not very good at getting myself set up, so here's how I usually end up playing:

- Making a primitive bow and arrows, then hunting while I gradually starve to death.
- Fishing (maybe with a fishing pole, maybe by stabbing the water repeatedly with a stick)... while I gradually starve to death.
- Setting a bunch of traps in apparently unfavorable areas. Getting frostbite (or just really frustrated) as I try to check them over and over, even though they haven't brought in any game.
- Finally making enough headway to build a cabin. Playing an awkward, hilarious, terrifying game of cat and mouse with a lynx that wanders onto my property, until I can manage to get a fence and traps up.

My last game, I started out trying to hunt with a bow/arrow. I brought down a bunch of birds with it, but I was gradually starving. I found a grouse that had been partially eaten by a goshawk. Fine, I'm not picky. That's a pound of grouse meat. I ate it. I was tracking a herd of reindeer for days, and when I went up to the mountain to scout out where they'd gotten to, I saw that there were wolves chasing them. I weighed the options, decided I was starving and I'd try to avoid the wolves. Came within a screen of wolves twice, but managed to avoid them, and found a reindeer that the wolves had taken down and started eating. Fine. I'm not picky. I skinned it, butchered it, and brought the meat home.

Finally, my trap pits started bringing in big game. Too much big game, in fact -- something like 4-5 reindeer and stags within the period of a week or so. I lost one of the hides when it rotted while I was scrambling to butcher everything, tan the hides, reset the traps, and haul meat up to the closest village before it went bad.

So I got sloppy and left a bunch of meat next to one of the traps, where I'd butchered a reindeer but couldn't carry everything back. When I came back for the rest, a wolf was there, attracted by the meat. He lunged at me and took me down in two attacks.

Anyway, if you like roguelikes or sandbox games, especially wilderness survival, get this. I always come back to it, that's how good it is, and it's constantly being improved (dynamic weather, predator-prey interaction, and more realistic animal spawning are all very new, and they're amazing, and I'm sure we can expect more of the same quality changes in the future). It's got a heck of a learning curve, but it basically defined sandbox games for me, way back before Minecraft was even a thing.

I've been playing Unreal World for a few years now, and for as impenetrable as it might look in some of the screenshots, it is actually one of the most understandable and playable roguelikes I've experienced.  It provides a real sense of accomplishment as well.

The first time I finally killed a large animal was as exciting as anything I've experienced in a game.  I had to sit back and just enjoy the accomplishment for several minutes.  When I made the mistake of building a fire too close to my log cabin that I had spent months (in game) and hours (in real life) building, and watched it burn down, I felt a real sense of loss, but also that I had learned something, and was ready to jump back in and try again.  The game's depth and pacing are, in my opinion, what set up these moments.

If you enjoy the survival genre, you owe it to yourself to give this a try.

An additional note: the development cycle for this game has been great over the years.  The developers (all two of them) keep the community informed and are constantly making improvements to the game.

I've been playing this game for years and it just keeps getting better and better with every iteration.  It's nice to see it up on steam where it will get more exposure and bring a great deal of enjoyment to many others who discover it.

It is a rich single-player world where you will have to survive.  No, not one wave after another of enemies, but the harsh realities of living in a land where even the weather can be your enemy.  Yes, there are some (NPC) people whom you might have to fight with, but many more whom you will trade with and develop a relationship for mutual survival.  You pick a spot to make your cabin.  Cut the trees to make the logs.  Fish.  Hunt.  Plant.  Make your tools or trade for them with nearby villagers.  Stock up on foods, make warm clothing and much, much more... and maybe,  just maybe, you'll survive the cold, dark winter.

I enjoy the turn-based aspect of this game, allowing me to go at my own pace.  Graphics are tiled top-down and not spectacular, but with each iteration of the game, they get better and better.  This latest version the graphics (particularly the lighting) add a lot to immersion.   It doesn't really matter though, because you soon get lost in the details and become immersed in the world no matter what.  How much snow fell while you were sleeping, do I need to use my skis?  Has it been cold enough to go out on the ice?  The edges of the lake are solid, but is the middle safe enough to walk on?  Did I hear a Elk in the distance to my left?  I better check my trap lines.  I wonder if the village I discovered earlier last week has some better spears to trade for.  There were  rumors of a bear in the area and it's hide would make nice warm clothing for cold winter days.... and on it goes.

Modding is easy and enjoyable, especially with this new version, allowing you to tweak many things or make completely new ones.  The creators of the game are also responsive to the community and very friendly.

I don't really have anything negative to say. It might take a little time to get used to the key commands, but the help file is easily accessible after hitting the ESC key.  The game does what it's suppose to and just gets better and more detailed with every iteration.  It's turn-based, survival, wilderness simulation that makes for a great afternoon or evening of play.  I'd say try it out, the price is very reasonable.

reviewText:
Have you ever wondered what being a Finn was like before the invention of alcoholism, anime, severe depression and murdering Russians? Well now, through the magic of computer roleplaying, you can at last find out!

This game is a pretty innovative blend of roguelike and survival simulator that dates back to several decades before the current survival game craze. The presentation and interface are true to that era, and so really shouldn't be a hindrance unless you're a millenial casual babby, in which case I congratulate you on managing to read this far without losing interest and playing with your smartphone, you little ♥♥♥♥.

The only area where this doesn't really hold is with certain repeated commands - putting down several fishing nets in succession involves a number of awkward key combinations, and the process of chopping down trees and hauling them to a location (which you WILL need to do if you want a house) will inevitably strain your fingers to the point where you will certainly come to sympathize with your likewise strained and fatigued character.

Besides that, the graphics are charming and effective - the sprites stand out, look good and tell you what you need to know, and the menus are decorated with quaint images of Finnish cosplayers in their natural habitat.

But enough about that nonsense! You want to hear about gameplay! The areas where this game really excels are its depth, realism and immersiveness. You begin play at a season of your choice, either in the wilderness or in a friendly, desolate or hostile settlement, depending on the starting scenario of your choice, equipped with either very little or nothing at all to help you weather the oncoming trials. From that point on, you have just one overarching goal: survive.

This isn't nearly as easy as you might think - not because everything is trying to kill you (in fact, the opposite is more likely to be true), but rather because getting the necessities of life is hard. Hunting, for example, requires that you first find prey - which involves a great deal of fruitless wandering and scouring the land for tracks. You might follow a fresh and promising trail to the point where you're only a hair's breadth away from your quarry, only to have it suddenly go cold, prompting profound disappointment. If you do find prey, your problems only multiply, as you then have to make a decision - do you close the distance and risk spooking the game in order to get a better shot? Or take the one you have, and risk missing to the same effect?

Managing risks and resources is in many ways the core of the gameplay. You have to choose not only how to conduct your activities, but which activities to embark on, as each have their associated risks and rewards. A hunt is likely to fail, can be dangerous, and is wont to leave you far from home and exhausted come night time. Fishing is safe, but consumes large amounts of your time and might return nothing at all, or an insufficient catch. There are no sure bets, however, and you'll inevitably have to go all in at some point. Sometimes you'll fail. That's just life.

Likewise, every activity has its associated costs. Not necessarily in resources, but always in your character's time and energy. Building a house will give you a leg up, but chopping down trees and hewing logs is hard work that's sure to leave you with an appetite, and to make it worse, all that time you spent doing that was time you didn't spend acquiring food. Consequently, much of the earlier game is an exercise in building a big enough stockpile to be able to do more time-intensive work without worrying about what you'll eat tomorrow. This is difficult, as the most easily acquired foods (fish and meat) spoil rapidly without some means to preserve them, and even if you do get lucky enough to kill an elk early on, there's no way you can eat all the resultant meat all by yourself before it will spoil.

Still, though, overcoming all of those challenges as they come at you brings on a sense of elation like little else in video games. Sure, half of it might just be dying in the cold and worrying about tomorrow's meals, and sure, the Njerpez will kill your favourite dog, and sure, you might acidentally give your pants away for a handful of peas, but everything becomes worth it when you can sit down and look with pride upon your big house, blooming fields and cellarful of dried meats. It's an extremely immersive game, equal parts harsh and rewarding, and frighteningly easy to get lost in. There's far less cannibalism involved than I remember from the last time I played it, but I would still highly recommend it if you're into deep and immersive sandbox RPGs.

reviewText:
I have been playing URW since 2001, version 2.60.  After 15 years it's awesome to finally see it come to the mainstream public attention, and I have nothing but praise for the game.

At its core, it's your basic roguelike game: perma-death, turn-based, keyboard-heavy and with 2d pixel tiles instead of fancy graphics. Actually, it started out way back (it's in development since 1992) as a fairly standard fantasy game, but then slowly transformed into a realistic life simulator in the setting of iron age Finland.

You will have to survive by crafting needed stuff, hunting/gathering/fishing/putting out traps and get food, wood and pelts to make items and/or to trade for things you can't craft like axes or pots, and get better armor and weapons to fight off wild beasts and nasty humans (they come in the form of either bloodthirsty Njerpez warriors that will only settle for your death, or simple robbers that will try to get your stuff either by talking or by bludgeoning you over the head). Also of course you'll get tired and need to sleep, eat, and drink.

The game has a day-night cycle, full-on weather and seasons system: in summer the temperatures are bearable even without being covered head to toe in furs, berries and plants to eat are readily available, there's plenty of game to hunt and life is generally easier (you will get mauled by a bear nonetheless, don't worry)

At the other end of the spectrum, winter is harsh: days are short and nights are long, it gets freezing cold and you WILL die from hypothermia so you have to build shelter, possibly an elaborate log cabin complete with fireplace, table and bed, make enough firewood to keep warm and get a decent source of food or a good plan for having enough in those long, boring months. Ice will cover the rivers and lakes so to fish you'll have to poke holes in it, and if you're not careful you can walk on thin ice that will break and drop you into freezing water. Also snow accumulates on the ground and unless you have skis, you won't be able to walk very long without getting incredibly tired so you better have everything you need not too far away. On the upside it also allows you to spot tracks much easier. Too bad there are few animals around in winter...

I could speak about the game all day but this would become too long, so I'll just say one last thing, and it's the thing that impressed me most:

This game is a labor of love. Over the many years I've been playing this, a LOT of things have changed, and always for the better. Just since last year or so, there's a totally new trading / reputation system with villages, most exploits have been squashed and replaced with sensible mechanics, you can command your pet dog and it's even more of a killing machine, new animal AI especially for predators that will actively hunt their prey (have sheeps in a pen? be careful of wolves!), addition of more birds and seals you can club, and the list goes on and on. It's a truly well supported game that is worth at least double what they're asking, so if you're interested in this kind of game and don't mind that it's keyboard-heavy and has 2d graphics, it is a MUST BUY.

Unreal World is an incredible example of what Roguelikes can be. In solid, continuous development since 1992, URW has no end in sight, with Enormous Elk (developers Sami and Erkka) continuing their work in bringing Iron Age Totally-Not-Finland to life.

URW is the epitome of survival games, yet predates the current craze by literally decades. It's realistic, it's tough, it's unforgiving, and extremely rewarding to play. There is a lot of depth and complexity to explore, and you can live your (probably short) life as a fisherman, hunter, trader, hermit, cannibal, raider... whatever strikes your fancy.

Roguelike mechanics, charming tileset graphics, and harsh survival interweaved with a touch of mysticism and the spirit of nature (which is simulated in great detail, from plants to animals to weather and seasons). Playing URW is simultaneously zen, and at times stressful (when you fall from a tree and break all your limbs and freeze to death, or almost anything to do with bears).

Highly recommended, and sold for a pittance. If you have doubts, check out the developers' website for the free version. If you find yourself enjoying the game, pitch in on Steam to support it years to come. This is a true labour of love, and with all things going well, will see years and years of improvements ahead.

reviewText:
Where do I start? UnReal World has been around and in active development a long time. The very first version was in 1992, which was vastly different from the game we have now. I personally have owned it for 10 years now, and in that time it has just kept getting better and better. I can't even begin to guess how many thousands of hours I've played this game over the years. I come back after every major update to find fresh new features to explore, with the basic meat of the game just as fun as I have always found it.

It's an amazing iron age survival simulation, the best I have played.

You create a character, choosing a tribe - each with their own genetics (affects attributes, height, build), knowledge (skills, auto-identification of certain plants, which rituals you might start with), and starting gear. Then you can select from a variety of starts to get things rolling - like being an escaping slave (good luck getting away from the camp full of your former masters) or an unfortunate hunting trip (will you kill the animal that killed your father, or flee?). You also pick which season to start in - each with their own challenges. From there you can either do the basic missions, which are there to get you acquainted with the game and give you attainable early goals; do the advanced missions, which are a bit more difficult and require more time; or just strike off and do your own thing.

Like any good survival game, you need to provide the basics for your character. You'll need a steady source of food - from hunting, fishing, trapping, foraging, farming, or trading. Just make sure you don't misidentify that mushroom and eat a poisoned one, and don't fall in your own trap pit - especially if you filled it with spikes.

You will also need shelter. Options here are a very basic lean to made from spruce branches, a kota (Finnish tent) made from hides that you can pack up and move with you, or a permanent log cabin. Having a smoke house with a fireplace comes in handy for smoking meat, which is one of the easiest ways to preserve your meat. Cellars are also handy to keep your food fresher longer. Need some help building your cabin? Hire a woodsman to cut some trees down for you, some good food may be all he wants.

And warm clothes are a must for when the temperature drops, so don't forget to skin that stag and tan its fur for a nice warm set of clothes. Or just for trading, a good fur is valuable. Maybe you'll use it to buy a dog to come along as your companion, helping to keep you safe from robbers and dangerous animals - just don't forget to feed it.

The hunting in this game is challenging and fun. Most animals are faster than you, but you have more endurance and you can sneak. Hounding an elk and running it down until it tires out is possible if your character's speed and endurance are decent, as long as you can track it well enough through the woods as it flees to keep on it. Especially if you manage to put an arrow or javelin in it when you first spot it, as a wounded animal runs slower. If you don't have luck actively hunting, you can set traps. From small loop snares all the way up to large lever traps and spiked trap pits, you can set a trap for whatever animal you're trying to hunt. Don't forget to bait them with meat if you're after carnivores.

If hunting isn't your style, you can fish. Fishing rods, clubs, or spears round out the active fishing options. Or get yourself a punt or raft and some nets for passive fishing.

Or be a farmer and supplement your diet with a variety of grown crops - peas, turnips, rye, beans, hemp, and more.

Or you could go straight up vegetarian, eating berries and bread and porridge and farmed vegetables. Just don't expect a vegetarian life to be easy in Iron Age Finland - meat and fish are the best sources of protein around. A balanced diet is easier to manage.

The animal AI in the game makes for some fun scenarios. Here is an example of a hunt I had recently:

I saw an Elk in the distance from the mountain near where I was building my homestead, and decide it's time to stock up on meat before the weather gets too hot for drying (started in Spring, still early enough).

I go hunting for it, and put an arrow in it when I find it - giving it a bleeding wound in the thorax. It runs and I begin the chase, relying on my good tracking skill and endurance to make up for its speed advantage. Soon I notice new tracks intermingled with the Elk. Bear tracks! I continue following the Elk, and the Bear tracks are right there with it all the way.

After a while of tracking I finally find my prey, still carrying my arrow... on the ground partially eaten! Bear tracks lead away to the west. As I already have plenty of meat right in front of me, I left my fellow hunter to his own devices and skinned and butchered the gift he left for me instead of going off after him.

It's little details like this that make this game amazing.

So what is Unreal World?

reviewText:
(dont get irritated by my play time, i have been playing URW since long before it was on steam)

Finally i can spend my time again in the far north, hunting Elk, drying their meat, tanning their skin to craft some warm winter clothes. I tried farming once, but in early summer an elk ravaged my fields and ate everything. The spirits seem to prefer me living a hunters life instead.

The AI is especially remarkable with realistic animal behaviour. They roam through the land, depending on the season, the terrain, spirits' favour and chance. The world is much more complex and dynamic than in other survival games such as the Long Dark.
There are loads and loads of plants. Dont know a mushroom because your herblore skill is too low? better dont eat it, you might get sick and die. Thank the spirits, there are also plants that help your body in a variaty of ways, some ease fever and help you getting rid of toxins. Or ease that flu you got after sleeping in the rain. Better know some. winter time? no plants for you then, except maybe some cloudberries that ripen extremely late in the year.

coolest crafting system i know. Want to smoke your meat because you cant eat the whole elk before it spoils? Well, you need a smoking hut. fell some trees, big ones. Make logs from the trunks, build walls. split some trunks into boards, make a door. get smaller trees and boards for the roof. a window, if you are fancy. For each step you need an axe. while it is possible to fell trees with a flimsy stone-axe, you better have some nice big axe (different axes are ideal for different work) or this will take a while...
collect a whole bunch of stones to build a stove. get firewood and smoke it up. dont forget some tying equipment to hang the meat from the roof (craftable from clothes or hides). And then the meat will taste terrible because your cooking skill is too low =)

A Bear mauled you? well this game has the most complex system of injuries i have ever seen in a game. if he just broke some ribs, lucky you. Maybe your legs are total waste and you cant stand up. good luck hunting now, you better have some emergency food stache to last you until everything is healed. Got a nice warm bear fur coat? good for you, but without gloves you'll get frostbite on your hands in winter. Better make a fire and warm yourself up regularly. You met a raider with a cuirass and your weapon is rather flimsy? aim for the legs and run! more than a dozen different zones of your body can get injured with different effects an armor parts realistically cover different parts. Different materials protect differently against point (e.g. spear, arrows), blade(sword), impact (club, reindeer hooves) damage and cold. bleeding is seperately discounted for. better have a bandage or you will bleed out, good if you know the blood staunching prayer.

awesome game and great support, too! for example there used to be a rare issue with the game not starting up on ubuntu. posted on the forum, the developer replied quickly and fixed it. The fix is coming in the next update and in the meantime he even provided beta access to the fix.

The community has a forum, a wiki and lots of friendly, helpful people you can ask if you like spearfishing but keep starving or if you are wondering where to find herbs to help dresssing wounds. Or just go and explore the unrealWorld yourself!

The game is turn based, but you can still get into trouble with burning your food if you go off and do a long consuming task or sleep, or you can have your food spoil if you do not eat it in a reasonable time or preserve it. There are NPC in the game whom you can trade with to get better quality gear which makes doing tasks much faster eg. chopping down trees with an iron axe instead of a stone axe. This game has more potential to come in the future. The game does lack music and sfx, there is some but could be more. But that really isnt important with the depth this game has under the hood.

Hands down one of the best roguelikes I've ever played. Played the free version on and off in the past before buying it on Steam to show my modest support and appreciation for the Devs.

Being developed and consistently updated for over 20 years, Unreal World is set in a world resembling ancient Finland in the Iron Age. The gameplay has a ton of freedom and depth, and the setting is rich in its historical atmosphere and lore.

There are many ways to play, you could be a farmer, hunter, a gatherer, a fisherman, a adventurer or trader as you find your path in this harsh, gritty world. There are no set rules, you decide where to go and what to do. Despite the simple graphics the gameplay is very realistic. It takes creativity and experience to accomplish some of the harder tasks like hunting. You really feel like you're part of the world as you make your way through the four seasons every year.

The game has its roots as a ASCII-based roguelike. If you've never played one of those before it might seem daunting to learn the controls, since for these games there're a lot of commands, akin to playing a flight simulator on the keyboard. It honestly isn't too hard to learn, and the in-game help browser and beginner game course is actually very helpful. If you don't mind learning the controls or if you're already a roguelike enthusiast like me, I highly recommend giving it a try.

reviewText:
UnReal World is an engaging survival roguelike with an amazing amount of depth.

You're alone in the wilderness set in the iron age of finland. You create a character from scratch with tons of skills at your disposal. The player is given a lot of freedom and tools which grants a lot of variety. You can play vastly different and try various survival tactics in order to overcome nature and it's threats. Be a fisherman, farmer, hunter, gatherer or a bandit. You're given the choice.

The world itself is vast and filled with tons of items, creatures, immersion, lore and danger. It's very intricate and engaging with a great amount of detail. Every task that action that you perform has consequences and keeping your characters alive is really a challenge, furthermore the entire game is designed in a realistic way which only enhances the immersion. From fishing to hideworking or combat, everything is rough and has detail. It's a engrossing and hostile world.

A great aspect is the interactive story, despite not having a full blown campaign. You can chose from a variety of character backgrounds which vastly changes the start of your adventure. Start as a well equipped hunter or fisherman but if you're up for the challenge you can play as a runaway slave that is being hunted. You make your own story and it's done with such detail that you feel really immersed. Even though the minimalistic graphics aren't that advanced, the presentation is solid. The small amount of songs and sound effect will still grab your attention, as for the rest the text provides enough flavor to really make you feel like this lonesome adventurer. This is pretty much standard for most roguelike though but this theme really resonates with me compared to other dungeon crawlers.

The interface and controls are somewhat unintuitive but once you get used to it, it's really not that much of a deal. It might be a hassle at first to browse through the various menus but it's all set up in a reasonable fashion. That might be the biggest issue about this game, also there aren't many sound effects but it's still solid enough.

Overall this is a very lovely game and crafted with such dedication, if this type of game doesn't appeal to you. You will probably get frustrated and not really enjoy it. But if you do, you will be rewarded with a great survival game that actually makes you think about provide a good challenge, while having a strong theme with a realistic tone.

Definitely worth the price. Even if you're not sure about this game, you can still download it for free on the official website.

To put into perspective the ungodly amount of effort that has gone into this game, I'll piont out that it has been in development since 1992. I *think* that makes it the game with the longest development time - at least more so than either Dwarf Frotress or the Duke Nukem. 24 years of work, as of the time of this review in 2016.

So what can you do in this game? Good question. You might recall how Todd Howard likes to say of Bethesda's releases that you can 'climb any mountain' or 'do anything' - well, you couldn't. In UrW you can come a whole lot closer to doing anything, though!

Every aspect of life (bar taking a ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥♥ing someone, which is probably for the best) is covered. A massive amount of attention to detail has been made, and there are absolutely shedloads of historically accurate items, foods and activites you can access. What's more, the game (despite being a roguelike and keyboard-based, which may initially pout a lot of people off) is very accessible due to its fantastic in-game wiki.

What I've always loved in particular is that you set your own goals, something that no other RPG I've ever seen has done so well:

* Want to hunt a bear? Sure, get tracking! But first you need to make sure you're well prepared. Should you take the spear, the bow or both? Is it worth buying a hunting dog to help you out? Maybe you'll need a companion from a local village to cover your back? How much food will you need for the journey? There are so many things to consider.

* Exploration is crazy in this game! I mean, the gameworld is literally Finland. The very size. It's enormous.

* Perhaps it's time to settle down; building a settlement in UrW is incredibly rewarding, but by no means easy work! I've never found anything as satisfying in a game as having completed a gleaming wooden longhall, complete with mead benches and a roaring hearth. It took me several in-game months to achieve and arrived just in time for winter. Winter is brutal in this game!

* If you somehow feel your options aren't already wide enough, the game is incredibly easy to mod! Making and adding mods are both simple processes and widely expand the gameplay; what's more, since modding for the most aprt relies on adding .txt and .png files, there's practically a 0% chance that you could damage your game with mods (unlike certain other franchises), so go crazy!

A final note is that the UrW forums having been running for years and in that time the developers Sami and Erkka have been amazing; they have listened to every player suggestion, answered every question they could and are highly aware of what can make the game better. There never has been, and never will be, a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ update. It's been getting better for 24 continuous years, and can only improve in the future! Make sure to visit the game's website and check the future development goals.

Thanks for reading this far!

Are you looking for a game with great graphics, immeaditely understandable UI, and steadily progressing storyline? Then this probably isn't the game for you. I'm going to be going through a couple of the points why I think someone wouldn't like this game, and then get to why I love it.

When they say open-ended, they mean it. You are literally dropped in the middle of the forest, with only the tools given to you. From here, you create your own story. Several background scenarios do add background, create added and varied challenges, and guide in the gameplay but at the end of the day, It's all up to you.

This is a game that has been in development for much of my life, and it shows. Check out the pictures of the game, the trailer, and the free version. If what you see UI and graphics wise is not your cup of tea, then you know what you are getting into.

Despite what I've mentioned above, this game is absolutely amazing once you do get into it. The multitude of positive reviews should hint to that fact. The mechanics and depth of gameplay implemented is quite amazing, the theme is very powerful and well developed, and the game simply has a way of making me long for getting back to nature.

Most importantly, it's the only game that I've been playing on and off for the past decade (well over, actually). It's a game I've been surprised by every time I play, finding new ways to survive and thrive (and, admittedly, die). It's a game I know I'll be checking out for the next decade as well.

Give it a couple of lives, read a survival guide, and then decide if it's a game for you. It's an investment that's well worth the effort.

reviewText:
Ignore what it says about my hours, I've put countless thousands into this game before it came to steam.

UnReal World (UrW) is quite simply the richest rogue-like survival in existence, unique in its depth and nuance. Create a character and determine your path to thriving (or dying) in dark ages Finland. Become a settled trapper, an itinerant fisher, a barbaric warmonger, a hunter, a farmer, a trader... many potential paths lie before you, and you may well find yourself taking all of them over the course of a character's life.

Foremost, UrW is both brutal and beautiful, crafting a deep narrative through your struggle to survive in a harsh world, where the environment itself can be as deadly as those that dwell in it. I could tell you a hundred stories from my times playing, of cunning victories, cozy campfires, and unexpected demises, but you'd be far better served spending that time creating your own.

In Brief:

Generate a unique world and roll a character to embark in it. You may also select a starting scenario (take the runaway slave in winter for hardcore mode or one of the training tutorials for a little early boost). From there, you must seek out a source of food, drink, and shelter. How you do so is truly in your hands. Craft items to aid in your endeavor. Collect berries and cook wonderful meals. Tire of lovely vegetarian fare. Set a fence trap and slaughter some wild beasts. Trade hides with foreign merchants for some coveted metal arms. Capture and tame a wild bear, then hire some fellow adventurers and raid a Njeperz camp. Cut their clothes into bandages and roast their bodies over open flames. And most important, establish a base camp to survive the coming cold, for WINTER _IS_ COMING.

If you die, it is permanent, which makes every encounter tense and rewarding. I really can't say enough how amazing this game is.

Finally, the developer Sami Maaranen is incredible in his dedication to his game and its playerbase. He is always responsive and friendly, and has been continually working on improving the UrW experience for over two decades. If there's anyone in the indie industry that deserves your money, it's him. I first bought UrW after saving for weeks at my minimum wage job in high school over a decade ago. What I got was worth ten times that.

BUY THIS GAME! DON'T WAIT! And then play it, and share your stories wide and far.

As I'm reading through the comments, I see mention that you can download and play the game from the developer's website. So I gave it a shot. So I've been playing a bunch for the last couple days and I'm really loving the game. At this point, I decided that I was going to buy this game and support the developer. This isn't some big company. It's a small indie thing and this guy has a huge set of cojones making his game available for free while also selling it on Stream. That shows confidence in your work. It IS that good. It's worth buying even though I could play it for free. I've already talked it up to a couple friends and they're going to try it out as well. Get the word of mouth going on this one.

So actually talking about the game itself. The graphics aren't anything to speak of but they don't need to be. This isn't a splashing graphical game for the Xbox crowd. This is an old school game but it's got depth that the old school games couldn't pull off. You start the world as a Nordic person back in the Iron Age. In most of the scenarios (there are many you can choose from) you start off alone. Usually you've got some basic supplies and a day or two worth of food. From here you've got to find food, build shelter, and stay alive! I've been starting in the summer. My goal has been to build a cabin before the winter hits. That's not an easy task. It's not like other survival games where it's simplified. Building takes lots of time and effort. Fishing, hunting, and trapping are difficult! It's easy to get lost in this game for hours.

Highly reccommended!

When you are used to get completly taken by your hand then you shouldn't play this game, but if you like to figure things out and get practiced in doing things, then this game is for you.
